question_text: Why can detonations propagate through unconﬁned detonable mixtures without congestion, whereas deﬂagrations require congestion to sustain overpressure? Explain the underlying physical principles.
standard_answer: Detonations can propagate through unconﬁned detonable mixtures without congestion because they are self-sustaining waves comprising a tightly coupled leading shock and reaction zone. The shock compresses and heats the unreacted mixture, triggering rapid chemical reactions that release energy, which in turn sustains the shock wave. This feedback loop allows detonations to maintain high velocities (~1800 m/s) and overpressures (~18 atm) independently of external obstructions. In contrast, deﬂagrations are subsonic combustion waves where burning is driven by molecular and turbulent transport. Congestion (obstacles) is necessary to sustain overpressure in deﬂagrations because it enhances turbulence, increasing flame surface area and burning rates, which generates and maintains pressure waves. Without congestion, the flame speed decays rapidly due to lack of turbulence generation, and overpressure decreases. The paper states: 'no congestion is necessary to sustain detonation propagation through the detonable mixture. In contrast to the case of a detonation, congestion is required to sustain the overpressure in deﬂagrations. Outside of the congested regions, the flame speed decays quickly and, therefore, the deﬂagration overpressure decreases quickly.' This fundamental difference arises from the detonation's reliance on shock dynamics versus the deﬂagration's dependence on diffusive and turbulent processes.
